title: simple_quarto_website
section: Is there a need for improved vitamin supplements?
text:
Is there a need for improved vitamin supplements?

Currently, over 40% of the world’s children are missing at least one vital nutrient. (Lamport, Christodoulou, and Achilleos 2020)
Creating a fiscally accessible, tasty vitamin could help to decrease the rate if vitamin deficiency in children.

title: simple_quarto_website
section: Should new supplementation target children or adults?
text:
Should new supplementation target children or adults?



Children
Children are well known to be at risk of vitamin deficiency. They are less able to self regulate their own diets, and the introduction of calorie dense, low nutrient foods(such as fast food) can lead to microdeficiencies.

40% are deficient



Adults
Adults are better at regulating diet and have greater means at changing their vitamin intakes. However, many adult vitamin supplements are unenjoyable.

Would an easier delivery through a chocolate shell lead to better supplementation?





Pros and Cons to Chocolate Supplementation



Pros
Cons




More Palatable
Could lead to overconsumption


Viable Delivery



Easy to Produce






Relative Change
We can predict the relative change in the percent of children who are vitamin deficient after introducing the chocolate supplement with: \[\% \Delta D = \dfrac{D_{before} - D_{after}}{D_{after}} \times 100\]
The absolute change, \(\Delta D = D_{before} - D_{after}\), can show us the exact change in number of deficient children.
Here’s what parents had to say about the new product:

My kid has been way more accepting of the chocolate supplement compared to before!

 





flowchart TD
    A[Do they eat our chocolate vitamin?] -->|Yes| B[They are probably NOT vitamin deficient!]
    A -->|No| C[They are probably vitamin deficient...]
